<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 380, 146]]<|/det|> Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 185]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 169, 256]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 213, 424, 261]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[623, 220, 722, 256]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[51, 201, 80, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 221, 919, 236]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[738, 213, 756, 248]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[52, 209, 80, 238]]<|/det|> <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 350, 296]]<|/det|> # ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 304, 156, 320]]<|/det|> Paper 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 335, 396, 352]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 361, 399]]<|/det|> No additional materials are needed. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 225, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 433, 294, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 464, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 495, 482, 510]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 551, 543]]<|/det|> - You should use a scientific calculator where appropriate. - You must show all necessary working clearly. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 556, 856, 573]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 589, 485, 604]]<|/det|> - For \(\pi\), use either your calculator value or 3.142. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 214, 649]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 649, 388, 666]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 80. - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 74, 567, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 105, 477, 124]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[601, 103, 786, 126]]<|/det|>
\[
(x-a)^{2}+(y-b)^{2}=r^{2}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 157, 537, 175]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[604, 157, 678, 173]]<|/det|>
\[
A=\pi r l
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 205, 372, 220]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[604, 201, 686, 220]]<|/det|>
\[
A=4 \pi r^{2}
\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[603, 246, 680, 276]]<|/det|>
\[
V=\frac{1}{3} A h
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 299, 336, 318]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[603, 292, 686, 321]]<|/det|>
\[
V=\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 347, 234, 364]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 345, 656, 364]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2}+b x+c=0\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 367, 559, 404]]<|/det|>
\[
x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 447, 225, 462]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 435, 907, 526]]<|/det|>
\[
(a+b)^{n}=a^{n}+\binom{n}{1} a^{n-1} b+\binom{n}{2} a^{n-2} b^{2}+\ldots+\binom{n}{r} a^{n-r} b^{r}+\ldots+b^{n},
\quad \text { where } n \text { is a positive integer and } \binom{n}{r}=\frac{n !}{(n-r) ! r !}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 554, 217, 569]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 552, 669, 599]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& u_{n}=a+(n-1) d \\
& S_{n}=\frac{1}{2} n(a+l)=\frac{1}{2} n\{2 a+(n-1) d\}
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 630, 217, 647]]<|/det|>
Geometric series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 628, 572, 710]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& u_{n}=a r^{n-1} \\
& S_{n}=\frac{a(1-r^{n})}{1-r} \quad(r \neq 1) \\
& S_{\infty}=\frac{a}{1-r} \quad(|r|<1)
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 739, 160, 754]]<|/det|>
Identities

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 736, 556, 790]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \sin ^{2} A+\cos ^{2} A=1 \\
& \sec ^{2} A=1+\tan ^{2} A \\
& \operatorname{cosec}^{2} A=1+\cot ^{2} A
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 829, 239, 846]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta A B C\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 823, 576, 900]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}=\frac{c}{\sin C} \\
& a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c \cos A \\
& \Delta=\frac{1}{2} a b \sin C
\end{aligned}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 76, 421, 95]]<|/det|>
1 A curve has equation \(y=x^{2}+2 x-3\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 109, 918, 126]]<|/det|>
（a）Use the method of completing the square to find the coordinates of the stationary point on the curve．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 326, 754, 343]]<|/det|>
（b）On the axes，sketch the curve，stating the intercepts with the coordinate axes．

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 372, 695, 651]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 366, 91]]<|/det|>
2 In this question, \(k\) is a constant. this question, \(k\) is a constant. It is given that \(2 x^{2}+(3 k-2) x+k=0\) has roots that are real and distinct.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 109, 373, 126]]<|/det|>
nd the set of possible values of v Find the set of possible values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 413, 443, 430]]<|/det|>
3 A sports club has the following members.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[362, 438, 637, 454]]<|/det|>
5 runners, 4 swimmers, 3 gymnasts

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 468, 463, 485]]<|/det|>
(a) These members stand in a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 500, 918, 516]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways that this can be done when all the runners stand together, all the swimmers stand together and all the gymnasts stand together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 669, 535, 685]]<|/det|>
(b) Four of these members are selected for an event.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 700, 918, 716]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways that this can be done when at least one runner, at least one swimmer and at least one gymnast must be selected.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 548, 91]]<|/det|>
4 The coordinates of points \(A, B, C\) and \(D\) are as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[328, 95, 669, 114]]<|/det|>
\[
A(-4,3) \quad B(6,-9) \quad C(15,10) \quad D(14,-1)
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 424, 146]]<|/det|>
The line \(L\) has equation \(y=11 x-75\). The perpendicular bisector of the line \(A B\) meets \(L\) at the point \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 175, 358, 192]]<|/det|>
Find the area of triangle \(C D E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 918, 102]]<|/det|>
5 Given that \(y=x^{2} \tan \frac{x}{2}\) ，use calculus to find the approximate change in \(y\) as \(x\) increases from \(\frac{\pi}{3}\) to \(\frac{\pi}{3}+h\) ，where \(h\) is small．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 921, 91]]<|/det|>
6 (a) Using an appropriate quadratic factorisation, find the first three terms in the binomial expansion of \(\left(9 x^{2}+12 x+4\right)^{5}, \quad\) in ascending powers of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 111, 443, 128]]<|/det|>
You must simplify your coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 464, 664, 510]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(\frac{6}{x^{2}}+\frac{x^{4}}{2}\right)^{12}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 606, 95]]<|/det|>
7 (a) The function f is defined by \(\mathrm{f}(x)=2 \mathrm{e}^{-x}+3\) for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 107, 918, 126]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y=\mathrm{f}(x)\) and hence, on the same axes, sketch the graph of \(y=\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 142, 264, 159]]<|/det|>
Show clearly - the positions of any points where your graphs meet the coordinate axes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 174, 485, 191]]<|/det|>
- the positions of any asymptotes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[305, 220, 695, 497]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 76, 623, 107]]<|/det|>
(b) The function g is defined by \(\mathrm{g}(x)=2-\frac{3}{\mathrm{e}^{x}+2}\) for \(x \geqslant 0\). Given that \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}\) exists, find an expression for \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}(x)\) and state its domain.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 623, 101]]<|/det|>
8 (a) Solve the equation \((2-3 \cot x) \cos x=0\) for \(0<x \leqslant \frac{\pi}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
(b) Solve the equation \(2 \operatorname{cosec}(2 \theta+1)-12 \sin (2 \theta+1)=5\), where \(\theta\) is in radians and \(-1 \leqslant \theta \leqslant 2\). [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 697, 91]]<|/det|>
9 In this question, all lengths are in centimetres and all angles are in radians.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 102, 516, 267]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 302, 623, 317]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector \(A O B\) of a circle, centre \(O\), radius 15 . Angle \(A O B=\frac{6 \pi}{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 347, 672, 363]]<|/det|>
The sector is made into a cone with points \(A\) and \(B\) touching, as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 378, 477, 393]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the curved surface area of the cone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 501, 439, 518]]<|/det|>
The top of the cone is a horizontal circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 532, 487, 549]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the circumference of the circular top.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 671, 788, 688]]<|/det|>
(c) Hence find the radius of the circular top and the perpendicular height of the cone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 391, 91]]<|/det|>
（d）Water is poured into the cone． When the depth of the water in the cone is \(h\) ，the radius of the circular top of the water is \(r\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 493, 138]]<|/det|>
（i）Find an expression for \(r\) in terms of \(h\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[152, 302, 769, 323]]<|/det|>
（ii）The water is poured into the cone at a constant rate of \(27 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) per second．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 336, 864, 353]]<|/det|>
Find the rate at which the depth of the water is rising when the depth of the water is 4 ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 405, 91]]<|/det|>
10 A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line. \(t\) seconds after passing a fixed point, \(O\), the acceleration of \(P, a \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\), is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[370, 123, 628, 165]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
a=t^{2}-2 & \text { for } 0 \leqslant t \leqslant 4 \\
a=19-5 \mathrm{e}^{8-2 t} & \text { for } 4 \leqslant t \leqslant 10
\end{array}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 187, 744, 218]]<|/det|>
When \(t=3\), the velocity of \(P\) is \(-\frac{1}{3} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) and its displacement from \(O\) is \(-\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 230, 465, 248]]<|/det|>
(a) (i) Find the velocity of \(P\) when \(t=4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[152, 493, 565, 510]]<|/det|>
(ii) Find the displacement of \(P\) from \(O\) when \(t=4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 76, 537, 92]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the displacement of \(P\) from \(O\) when \(t=10\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 76, 703, 91]]<|/det|>
11 A geometric progression has first term \(a\) and common ratio \(r\), where \(r>0\). The sum of the 2nd and 3rd terms of the progression is 168.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 107, 584, 122]]<|/det|>
The sum of the 4th and 5th terms of the progression is 94.5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 443, 153]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the 6th term of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 583, 493, 602]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the sum to infinity of the progression.
